image.altText: Tokyo bedroom

items.synopsis: We challenged four reporters to find somewhere to live for 30 per cent of the average wage in their global cities. From "dorms for adults" to buildings that could be demolished at any moment, they saw it all.

title.children: What does your rent money get you around the world?

image.altText: An infant plays with a yellow box while his parents look at him, in a domestic setting.

items.synopsis: A growing number of Australians are defaulting on their home loans as the number of borrowers at risk of mortgage stress peaks at levels not seen since the global financial crisis.

title.children: 'A perfect storm': New figures reveal extent of mortgage stress ahead of next week's interest rates decision

image.altText: A man in a dark suit leans over a map

items.synopsis: Over the last week focus on the war has been diverted by the plane crash in Russia which is believed to have killed the leader of the Wagner mercenary group Yevgeny Prigozhin, but there are bigger questions, writes John Lyons.

title.children: Fears of a post-Putin Russia have frozen the US

image.altText: Richard Marles says AUKUS submarine project will incur 'significant' cost for Australian economy

items.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happens.

title.children: Richard Marles extends condolences after 'tragic' helicopter crash kills three US marines. The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese will travel to Adelaide on Wednesday to announce the date for the Voice to Parliament referendum. Yes campaigner Thomas Mayo told ABC News Breakfast they had almost 30,000 volunteers working towards a Yes vote. "There's around 30 to 40% of Australians that haven't made up their minds yet and those are the people that we'll be focusing on," he said. When asked whether he was worried the Yes campaign may get a majority of votes nationally but not the majority of states, Mayo said the Yes campaign was focusing on speaking to all Australians. "We're not taking any state for granted. "We're not writing off any states, not Queensland, not WA."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Yes campaign 'not taking any state for granted'

children.content: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese will travel to Adelaide on Wednesday to announce the date for the Voice to Parliament referendum.
Thomas Mayo
(ABC)
Yes campaigner Thomas Mayo told ABC News Breakfast they had
almost 30,000 volunteers working towards a Yes vote.
"There's around 30 to 40% of Australians that haven't made
up their minds yet and those are the people that we'll be focusing on," he said.
When asked whether he was worried the Yes campaign may get a majority of votes nationally but not the majority of states, Mayo said the Yes campaign was focusing on speaking to all Australians.
"We're not taking any state for granted.
"We're not writing off any states, not Queensland,
not WA."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A cruise ship has collided with a petrol tanker off the Spanish tourist island of Mallorca. P & O Cruises says a small number of people have been injured and are being cared for onboard the vessel. Port authorities in the capital Palma say the incident was caused by high winds. Heavy rains have swept across Mallorca over the weekend, and flights from Barcelona were delayed because of the high winds.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Cruise ship collides with petrol tanker off Mallorca

children.content: A cruise ship has collided with a petrol tanker off the Spanish tourist island of Mallorca.
P
O Cruises says a small number of people have been injured and are being cared for onboard the vessel.
Port authorities in the capital Palma say the incident was caused by high winds.
Heavy rains have swept across Mallorca over the weekend, and flights from Barcelona were delayed because of the high winds.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Here's some lighter news for your Monday morning. Thousands of people gathered in the Netherlands over the weekend for the annual Redhead Days Festival in the southern town of Tilburg. Organisers say some 5,000 redheads from different countries visited the festival, which offered workshops on painting, make-up and skin care tips, photo shoots, music and speed meet events. "I don't feel alone anymore, I feel together, a part of something," Scottish Liam Hunter said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Thousands of redheads celebrate at festival

children.content: In 2013 the festival entered the Guinness World Records book .
(Reuters: Piroschka van de Wouw)
Here's some lighter news for your Monday morning.
Thousands of people gathered in the Netherlands over the weekend for the annual Redhead Days Festival in the southern town of Tilburg.
Virginia, 47, from Paris at the annual Redhead Days Festival.
(Reuters: Piroschka van de Wouw)
Organisers say some 5,000 redheads from different countries visited the festival, which offered workshops on painting, make-up and skin care tips, photo shoots, music and speed meet events.
"I don't feel alone anymore, I feel together, a part of something," Scottish Liam Hunter said.

image.altText: An ambulance and a helicopter are in a strip of runway with paramedics working.

items.synopsis: Three US marines have died and five are being treated in hospital after a US military aircraft crashed on a remote island off the coast from Darwin. Here's what we know.

title.children: What we know about the aircraft crash that killed three US marines

image.altText: A close up image of drinks from Chatime, with a purple lid.

items.synopsis: Whether it is wage theft, outdated enterprise agreements, or traineeships subsidised by the government, an ominous cloud has hung over the country's labour force for years, writes Adele Ferguson.

title.children: The Chatime underpayment penalty will send a message to those at the top of the franchising sector

image.altText: daniel andrews tours ballarat's eureka stadium at announcement of 2026 commonwealth games

items.synopsis: Victoria's cancellation of the 2026 regional Commonwealth Games is under scrutiny today, as a Senate inquiry holds hearings in Melbourne. Follow live.

title.children: Commonwealth Games inquiry explores Victorian cancellation in public hearing

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Senator Bridget McKenzie is now turning to the future and who could host the 2026 Games. She's asking who Commonwealth Games Australia is talking to "about finding an Australian solution to what is essentially an Australian problem?" Mr Phillips says efforts so far have been caught up with the compensation agreement, leaving only time for preliminary discussions with Gold Coast mayor Tom Tate. "Beyond that, no one," Mr Phillips says. Reporting by Melissa Brown
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Gold Coast a possible 'Australian solution' to 2026 Games

children.content: Senator Bridget McKenzie is now turning to the future and who could host the
2026 Games
She's asking who
Commonwealth Games Australia
is talking to "about finding an Australian solution to what is essentially an Australian problem?"
Preliminary conversations have been held with the Gold Coast mayor.
(ABC News: Michael Lloyd)
Mr Phillips says efforts so far have been caught up with the compensation agreement, leaving only time for preliminary discussions with
Gold Coast mayor Tom Tate
"Beyond that, no one," Mr Phillips says.
Reporting by Melissa Brown

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The hearing has kicked off, with chair Matt Canavan announcing today's hearings will be focusing on the Victorian events. Commonwealth Games Australia president Ben Houston has told the committee his organisation won't be making any further comment on the $380 million compensation settlement with Victoria. He says that's in the interests of trying to find a new host for the games. He says he hopes a host can be found in Australia. "When it was announced in April last year, the 2026 home games was universally acknowledged as an accelerator for Brisbane 2032 (Olympic Games) and we remain committed to that outcome," Mr Houston says. Reporting by Melissa Brown
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Commonwealth Games Australia won't comment further on $380m compensation

children.content: The hearing has kicked off, with chair Matt Canavan announcing today's hearings will be focusing on the Victorian events.
Commonwealth Games Australia president Ben Houston
has told the committee his organisation won't be making any further comment on the
$380 million compensation settlement
with Victoria.
He says that's in the interests of trying to find a new host for the games.
He says he hopes a host can be found in Australia.

"When it was announced in April last year, the 2026 home games was universally acknowledged as an accelerator for Brisbane 2032 (Olympic Games) and we remain committed to that outcome," Mr Houston says.
Reporting by Melissa Brown

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Here's the witness list for today's hearings, which are now underway: There are several witnesses from Commonwealth Games Australia : Mr Craig Phillips AM, Chief Executive Officer Mr Ben Houston, President and Chief Executive Officer Ms Petria Thomas, Chef de Mission Ms Ellie Cole, Deputy Chef de Mission And witnesses from Ernst and Young, the consulting firm which carried out costings for the government: Mr Dean Yates, Partner Mrs Leigh Walker, Partner Other witnesses include voices from Geelong: Mr Michael Johnston, Chief Executive Officer, Committee for Geelong Ms Guilia Baggio, Chief Executive Officer, Geelong Region Alliance — G21 As well as Simon Thewlis from Event Pty Ltd, VicSport CEO Lisa Hasker and Bass Coast Shire mayor Michael Wheelan. Former Victorian tourism and sports minister Martin Pakula will give evidence in the afternoon.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Who is set to appear today?

image.altText: A mining truck carrying iron ore on a remote mine site.

items.synopsis: Local shares could make gains as reporting season continues, and the chief executive of Fortescue leaves after less than six months. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX looks set to rise, Fortescue boss gone

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The number of borrowers at risk of mortgage stress has hit levels not seen since 2008, new research shows. Figures from Roy Morgan reveal 1.5 million, or 29 per cent, of borrowers were at risk of mortgage stress in July 2023 — a number higher than during the global financial crisis. While the percentage of affected people is lower than in 2008, the number of Australians at risk is higher due to growth in the population and the number of people in the mortgage market. The report also shows the number of borrowers battling to pay off loans has steadily risen since the RBA began its aggressive run of interest rate rises in May last year. It comes ahead of a speech from incoming Reserve Bank governor Michelle Bullock, who will speak in Canberra tomorrow evening before she takes up the job mid-next month. You can read the full story on mortgage stress from Kathryn Diss here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 1.5m borrowers at risk of mortgage stress: Roy Morgan

featuredLink.title: 'I don't have that buffer': New figures reveal mortgage stress exceeds levels seen during GFC

(Roy Morgan)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: After only taking up the top job in February, the chief executive of Fortescue Metals Fiona Hick is leaving the miner. In a surprise announcement to the stock exchange this morning, Fortescue revealed Dino Otranto as the new CEO. Ms Hick's exit is described as a "joint decision with the board" and as "friendly and mutual" — she will be leaving the company altogether. "We thank Fiona for her valuable efforts since joining Fortescue just under six months ago and wish her all the best with her future pursuits," executive chairman Andrew Forrest said. Dino Otranto joined Fortescue in 2021 as chief operating officer of the iron ore division.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Fortescue boss exits after a matter of months

children.content: After only taking up the top job in February, the
chief executive of Fortescue Metals Fiona Hick is leaving
the miner.
In a
surprise announcement
to the stock exchange this morning,
Fortescue revealed Dino Otranto as the new CEO
Ms Hick's exit is described as a "joint decision with the board" and as "friendly and mutual" — she will be leaving the company altogether.
"We thank Fiona for her valuable efforts since joining Fortescue just under six months ago and wish her all the best with her future pursuits," executive chairman Andrew Forrest said.
Dino Otranto joined Fortescue in 2021 as chief operating officer of the iron ore division.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Hello, Stephanie Chalmers here to bring you through the day's market action. And with ASX futures pointing higher, it could be a good start to the week for the local share market in just over an hour's time. It follows US markets ending higher on Friday, as traders digested comments from Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell at a central banker summit. Speaking at the annual Jackson Hole Economic Policy Symposium in Wyoming, Mr Powell indicating that while US interest rates may need to rise further, the Fed would proceed with caution. "We will proceed carefully as we decide whether to tighten further or, instead, to hold the policy rate constant and await further data," he said. "It is the Fed’s job to bring inflation down to our 2 per cent goal, and we will do so." On the local front, reporting season continues with results from companies including Fortescue due today. The ABS will release retail sales figures for July mid-morning — so stick around through the day for all the latest!
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Good morning (maybe for markets too)

image.altText: A storefront with a big yellow sign reading dollar general on top with green grass and trees in front and police man and cars

title.children: Man who killed three in 'racially motivated' shooting bought guns legally, had no criminal record, Florida police say

title.children: How VR is giving babies in the outback a better shot at birth

image.altText: A wombat walks out of a burrow

items.synopsis: With only 315 of the marsupials left, conservationists are using subsurface mapping to investigate the wombats' burrows in a bid to find potential new habitats for the critically endangered species.

title.children: With just 315 northern hairy-nosed wombats left, conservationists are looking to map their underground homes

image.altText: A man with glasses and brown flannelette shirt sits on a purple outdoor chair.
